awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Channel Coding Paradigms for Next-Generation Storage Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
We are now in the midst of a technological revolution of massive data generation and processing. Equally massive data storage is required to support this technological boom. New solutions cognizant of operational constraints of storage systems must be invented to curb the skyrocketing cost of data storage. Fundamentally common to all storage technologies are channel coding schemes. Results from coding theory have been used with phenomenal success in storage systems. Practical coding schemes have helped make computer storage ubiquitous. However, currently available coding schemes have hit a performance wall: existing codes are designed for simple channels, and do not match the needs of new storage technologies where the data must be packed as densely as possible on increasingly adverse mediums. Such performance provisioning not only violates fundamental information-theoretic laws but directly increases the cost of a storage system.

This research fundamentally rethinks channel coding methods with applications to storage systems. This project creates a coding-theoretic foundation that embraces, rather than ignores, adverse physical and operating conditions to increase the capacity of the upcoming storage technologies. Rich combinatorial structure of non-binary channel codes is explored and exploited over four research thrusts: (a) analysis and design of structured non-binary low-density parity-check codes, (b) theory and practice of non-binary non-symmetric error correcting codes, (c) non-binary methodologies for overcoming synchronization errors, and (d) theory-based rapid code prototyping using novel algorithms for fast simulation, FPGA implementation, and publicly available on-line evaluation tool. This research project contributes to the development of a competitive American workforce through active and carefully tailored research engagement of high-school, undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Channel coding methods are mathematical techniques that are used to improve reliability of noisy storage and communication channels by way of adding controlled amount of redundancy into data prior to storage/transmission. This redundancy is expressed through carefully designed equations. Channel coding methods are employed in all practical data storage systems. This project substantially improved state of the art in channel coding methods for modern data storage. We developed novel graph-based and algebraic channel codes for a variety of new storage technologies, including ultra dense hard disk drives and Flash memories. These included innovations in nonbinary low-density parity-check codes, coding for write once memories, variability-aware coding for non-volatile memories, and rank modulation coding, and have used sophisticated tools and techniques from abstract algebra, combinatorics, optimization, number theory, and other mathematical disciplines. Results were disseminated through peer reviewed research articles and presentations, and a survey monograph. Several of our solutions have found use in disks built by leading data storage companies. Ample research opportunities were provided to graduate and undergraduate students as well as researchers from underrepresented groups. Results from this project have been incorporated into existing graduate and undergraduate classes at UCLA, and a new graduate class at UCLA has been developed based in part on the results and findings in this project.
